Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Internship in Supercomputing for Physical Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the renewal of a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities for the summers of 2008-2010. This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program in the Division of Chemistry (CHE). The program will be directed by David Thomas of the Department of Biochemistry, Molecular Biology, and Biophysics at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities. Seven additional faculty members, who are computational experts in the Institute of Technology and the Medical School, will serve as research advisors. This REU site will bring eight students to the Minnesota Supercomputing Institute for a ten-week period each summer to conduct-cutting edge research in the use of supercomputing methods in the physical sciences. Individual student projects have been developed around this theme of scientific visualization and graphics. Undergraduate students will be recruited nationally particularly from institutions with limited opportunities for undergraduate research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
REU grant 0755186 funded 24 undergraduate students for 10-week research internships at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities during the summers of 2008, 2009, and 2010. The students worked on projects at the Minnesota Supercomputing Institute (MSI), a research center that provides high-performance computing resources to University of Minnesota faculty and their research groups.

The interns were each assigned to a faculty mentor who oversaw their work. Many MSI interns are students at smaller colleges that don’t have a research component, and this program gave them the chance to participate in cutting-edge research using scientific computing. MSI’s intern program includes projects in a number of scientific fields; the common thread of the program is the use of the computational resources at MSI, which include high-performance computing (HPC) on supercomputers, high-end professional graphics workstations, and the use of advanced, specialized software to perform research. Interns in our program worked on projects in chemistry, biochemistry, medicinal chemistry, geophysics, physics, astronomy, and computer science. The students came from 14 colleges and universities throughout the U.S. plus the University of Minnesota Twin Cities.

The interns’ projects are part of the larger research efforts of their faculty mentors. The faculty who participated in this program all have active, high-quality research programs. The group includes senior professors with many years’ standing as outstanding educators and numerous teaching awards and younger professors who are making their marks both as teachers and as researchers. Interns in this program do their own work, they do not just shadow the graduate students and post-docs. They are assigned a specific project of their own that supports the group’s work. As a result, interns often contribute to papers published in professional journals, which benefits them as well as contributing to the advancement of the discipline. As of May 2011, five interns sponsored by this REU (Daniel J. Kennedy [2008 intern], Jonathan C. McLane [2008 intern], Abhrajeet Roy [2008 intern], Jessica M. Schmidt [2008 intern], Robin M. Weiss [2009 intern]) have been co-authors on papers that have appeared in professional journals and books, and more publications are in preparation.

Academic requirements of the program include seminars, presentations, and written reports. Interns attend weekly lunchtime seminars hosted by the faculty mentors, who talk about their research and their use of scientific computing. We also provide a seminar on giving presentations. At the end of the summer, the interns give a presentation and write a report about their research project. The audience for the presentations consists of their fellow interns, the faculty mentors and research groups, and members of the MSI staff. The presentation and report give the interns an opportunity to practice their public-speaking and writing skills, which we feel is beneficial whether or not the students go on to graduate school.

The intern program gives the students a research experience that will help them decide if graduate education and/or a teaching career is right for them. Because of the varied projects available in the MSI program, interns can also learn about other disciplines and meet students at other colleges and universities throughout the U.S. MSI interns are also given the opportunity to socialize with undergraduate interns from other departmental programs. Other benefits from this program extend to the graduate students and post-docs that work with the interns, by giving them the chance to improve their own teaching and mentoring skills.
